member.name: P:Phidget22.DigitalOutput.LEDForwardVoltage
member.remarks:
The LEDForwardVoltage is the voltage that will be available to your LED.
Reference the data sheet of the LED you are using before setting this value. Choose the LEDForwardVoltage that is closest to the forward voltage specified in the data sheet.
This forward voltage is shared for all channels on this device. Setting the LEDForwardVoltage on any channel will set the LEDForwardVoltage for all channels on the device.

member.name: P:Phidget22.MotorPositionController.CurrentRegulatorGain
member.remarks: Depending on power supply voltage and motor coil inductance, current through the motor can change relatively slowly or extremely rapidly. A physically larger DC Motor will typically have a lower inductance, requiring a higher current regulator gain. A higher power supply voltage will result in motor current changing more rapidly, requiring a higher current regulator gain. If the current regulator gain is too small, spikes in current will occur, causing large variations in torque, and possibly damaging the motor controller. If the current regulator gain is too high, the current will jitter, causing the motor to sound 'rough', especially when changing directions. Each DC Motor we sell specifies a suitable current regulator gain.

member.name: P:Phidget22.MotorPositionController.MinCurrentRegulatorGain
member.remarks: The minimum current regulator gain for the device.

member.name: P:Phidget22.MotorPositionController.MaxCurrentRegulatorGain
member.remarks: The maximum current regulator gain for the device.

member.name: P:Phidget22.MotorPositionController.MaxDataInterval
member.remarks: The maximum value that DataInterval can be set to.

member.name: P:Phidget22.MotorPositionController.Kd
member.remarks: Derivative gain constant. A higher Kd will help reduce oscillations.

member.name: P:Phidget22.MotorPositionController.Ki
member.remarks: Integral gain constant. The integral term will help eliminate steady-state error.

member.name: P:Phidget22.MotorPositionController.Kp
member.remarks: Proportional gain constant. A small Kp value will result in a less responsive controller, however, if Kp is too high, the system can become unstable.

member.remarks: The lower bound of StallVelocity.

member.name: P:Phidget22.RCServo.SpeedRampingState
member.remarks: When speed ramping state is enabled, the controller will take the Acceleration and Velocity properties into account when moving the RC servo motor, usually resulting in smooth motion. If speed ramping state is not enabled, the controller will simply set the RC servo motor to the requested position.

member.name: P:Phidget22.RCServo.VelocityLimit
member.remarks:
When moving, the RC servo motor velocity will be limited by this value.
The velocity limit is bounded by MinVelocityLimit and MaxVelocityLimit.
SpeedRampingState controls whether or not the velocity limit value is actually applied when trying to reach a target position.
The velocity range of the RC servo motor will be from -VelocityLimit to VelocityLimit, depending on direction.
Note that when this value is set to 0, the RC servo motor will not move.
There is a practical limit on how fast your servo can rotate, based on the physical design of the motor.
The units for Position,Velocity, and Acceleration are configured by scaling the internal timing (set with MinPulseWidth and MaxPulseWidth) to a user specified range with MinPosition and MaxPosition.

member.name: P:Phidget22.RCServo.MinVelocityLimit
member.remarks: The minimum velocity VelocityLimit can be set to.

member.name: P:Phidget22.RCServo.MaxVelocityLimit
member.remarks: The maximum velocity VelocityLimit can be set to. This value depends on MinPosition/MaxPosition and MinPulseWidth/MaxPulseWidth.

member.name: P:Phidget22.VoltageInput.SensorType
member.remarks:
We sell a variety of analog sensors that do not have their own API, they simply output a voltage that can be converted to a digital value using a specific formula. By matching the SensorType to your analog sensor, the correct formula will automatically be applied to data when you get the SensorValue or subscribe to the SensorChange event.
The SensorChange event has its own change trigger associated with it: SensorValueChangeTrigger.
Any data from getting the SensorValue or subscribing to the SensorChange event will have a SensorUnit associated with it.Note: Unlike other properties such as DeviceSerialNumber or Channel, SensorType is set after the device is opened, not before.

member.name: P:Phidget22.VoltageInput.SensorUnit
member.summary: The sensor unit information corresponding to the SensorValue.
member.remarks:
The unit of measurement that applies to the sensor values of the SensorType that has been selected.
Helps keep track of the type of information being calculated from the voltage input.

member.name: P:Phidget22.VoltageInput.MinVoltage
member.remarks: The minimum value the VoltageChange event will report.

member.name: P:Phidget22.VoltageInput.MaxVoltage
member.remarks: The maximum value the VoltageChange event will report.

member.name: P:Phidget22.VoltageInput.MinVoltageChangeTrigger
member.remarks: The minimum value that VoltageChangeTrigger can be set to.

member.name: P:Phidget22.VoltageInput.MaxVoltageChangeTrigger
member.remarks: The maximum value that VoltageChangeTrigger can be set to.

member.name: E:Phidget22.VoltageInput.SensorChange
member.remarks:
The most recent sensor value the channel has measured will be reported in this event, which occurs when the DataInterval has elapsed.
If a SensorValueChangeTrigger has been set to a non-zero value, the SensorChange event will not occur until the sensor value has changed by at least the SensorValueChangeTrigger value.
This event only fires when ${PROPERTY:SensorType} is not set to SENSOR_TYPE_VOLTAGE

member.name: E:Phidget22.VoltageInput.VoltageChange
member.remarks:
The most recent voltage value the channel has measured will be reported in this event, which occurs when the DataInterval has elapsed.
If a VoltageChangeTrigger has been set to a non-zero value, the VoltageChange event will not occur until the voltage has changed by at least the VoltageChangeTrigger value.
If ${PROPERTY:SensorType} is supported and set to anything other then SENSOR_TYPE_VOLTAGE, this event will not fire.

member.name: P:Phidget22.VoltageRatioInput.SensorType
member.remarks:
We sell a variety of analog sensors that do not have their own API, they simply output a voltage that can be converted to a digital value using a specific formula. By matching the SensorType to your analog sensor, the correct formula will automatically be applied to data when you get the SensorValue or subscribe to the SensorChange event.
The SensorChange event has its own change trigger associated with it: SensorValueChangeTrigger.
Any data from getting the SensorValue or subscribing to the SensorChange event will have a SensorUnit associated with it.Note: Unlike other properties such as DeviceSerialNumber or Channel, SensorType is set after the device is opened, not before.

The unit of measurement that applies to the sensor values of the SensorType that has been selected.
Helps keep track of the type of information being calculated from the voltage ratio input.

The most recent sensor value the channel has measured will be reported in this event, which occurs when the DataInterval has elapsed.

member.name: E:Phidget22.VoltageRatioInput.VoltageRatioChange

If ${PROPERTY:SensorType} is supported and set to anything other then SENSOR_TYPE_VOLTAGERATIO, this event will not fire.

member.name: P:Phidget22.Phidget.InvokeEventCallbacks
member.summary: When true, event callbacks will be called via Invoke() if Invoke is required.
member.remarks:
Calling events via Invoke allows you to access the GUI directly from the event callbacks. However, this can lead to hard to debug dead-lock behaviour is code is not written carefully, so this should be disabled.
However, this is enabled by default to maintain the same behaviour as phidget21.

member.name: M:Phidget22.Phidget.Open
member.remarks:
Opens the Phidget channel. The specific channel to be opened can be specified by setting any of the following properties:
DeviceSerialNumber
DeviceLabel
Channel
ServerName
IsLocal
IsRemote
HubPort
HubSerialNumber
HubLabel
IsHubPortDeviceOpen will return immediately, with the open proceding asynchronously.Use the Attach event or Attached property to determine when the channel is ready to use.

member.name: M:Phidget22.Phidget.Open(System.Int32)
member.remarks:
Opens the Phidget channel.The specific channel to be opened can be specified by setting any of the following properties:
DeviceSerialNumber
DeviceLabel
Channel
ServerName
IsLocal
IsRemote
HubPort
HubSerialNumber
HubLabel
IsHubPortDeviceOpen will block until the channel is opened or a timeout occurs. A timeout value of 0 will wait forever.

member.name: M:Phidget22.Phidget.WriteDeviceLabel(System.String)
member.remarks:
Writes a label to the device in the form of a string in the device flash memory. This label can then be used to identify the device, and will persist across power cycles.
The label can be at most 10 UTF-16 code units. Most unicode characters take up a single code unit, but some, such as emoji, can take several.
Some devices can not have their labels set from Windows. For these devices the label should be set from Linux or macOS.
See using a label for more information about how to use labels with Phidgets.
